entry.title: New River Landscape・新しい川の風景

link.title: New River Landscape・新しい川の風景

entry.content:
View of the recently finished Fukuda Art Museum (left) and Muni Hotel (right). A pair of modern designs which fit in with the existing, more traditional, buildings along the Katsura (Oi) River, just beyond the Togetsu Bridge.

Now that construction has been completed, we can finally enjoy the view of the river with green mountains behind.

entry.title: Somen・そうめん
entry.content:
Cold somen (thin white noodles) on a bed of ice, topped with shrimp, mushroom, omelette pieces, and a twist of cucumber; to be dipped into a light soy-based sauce, garnished with scalions and wasabi.

Part of a multi-course lunch at Arashiyama’s Nishiki Restaurant, a place I have been visiting for 30 years.

entry.title: Gion Matsuri Lanterns・祇園祭提灯

link.title: Gion Matsuri Lanterns・祇園祭提灯

entry.content:
Shijo-dori street at dusk, with hanging lanterns to celebrate the cancelled Gion Matsuri, a festival of purification and pacification of disease causing entities that takes place throughout July, including two large parades. The Gion Matsuri has been an annual event for over a thousand years, but not this year.

Seems like this year might be a good time to pacify disease causing entities, but science has won out over superstition.

entry.title: Okochi Sanso Teahouse・大河内山荘の滴水庵

link.title: Okochi Sanso Teahouse・大河内山荘の滴水庵

entry.content:
Lush green garden in front of the Tekisuian teahouse at Okochi Sanso villa, created by period film star Denjiro Okochi.

Japanese tea houses are typically spartan affairs; small, simple spaces with minimal ornamentation in order to appreciate the tea ceremony and commune with nature.
